answer: The author concludes the story with this because gardens cannot grow with snow on the ground. So she figures when all the snow is melted she'll try to grow another one. The narrator explains that when the guests arrive and the hibiscus flowers are blooming, it signifies the arrival of spring once again. This connection between the presence of guests and the blossoming of the hibiscus highlights the cyclical nature of the seasons and the joy that comes with the renewal of life in springtime. The vibrant colors of the hibiscus and the lively atmosphere created by the guests evoke a sense of rejuvenation and celebration. Overall, the narrator's observation captures the essence of spring as a time of growth, beauty, and shared happiness among friends and family.

The author concludes the story with that passage to show the importance of the inspiration Saeng gets from the hibiscus plant. Saeng, throughout the story was comforted by the hibiscus plant because it reminded her of home. The plant during the winter metaphorically explains Saeng's attitude towards her new country and her driving test; the hibiscus plant in the winter is not as beautiful in the bitter cold, but it adapts and survives, and returns to its beautiful state in the spring. Saeng is bitter about her new country and driving test, but is adapting, and will be inspired by the beautiful state of the hibiscus in the spring to try her test again. In conclusion, the author ended the story in that way to stress importance in the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus plant.

Saeng realized that many of the things she thought were strange were almost familiar to her now, like the calls of the snow geese and the melting snow signaling the arrival of spring. As the winter hibiscus prepared to bloom once again, Saeng felt a sense of hope and renewal. She knew that with the changing of the seasons, she too would undergo a transformation. Perhaps this spring, she would finally pass the test and make her mother proud. Slowly but surely, Saeng was beginning to feel at home in her new country, leaving behind the nostalgia for her life in Vietnam.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the author wanted to tell about when Saeng will take the test again. The author told the time with the season of the spring. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. And so, as the seasons changed and nature awakened once more, Saeng's resolve remained firm, ready to try again when the time was right.

As the clock ticked closer to the end of the test, Sarah's heart raced with anticipation. She had studied diligently this time, determined not to repeat the same mistake she made before. The weight of her previous failure loomed over her, driving her to focus with unwavering intensity. Finally, as she clicked the submit button, a wave of relief washed over her. Now, all she could do was wait for the results, hoping that her hard work had paid off.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, the girl buys a Hibiscus that reminds her of home and brings it back to her new home in America. Despite failing her test, she finds comfort in the familiar beauty of the plant. As she plants it, she is greeted by the sight of geese flying overhead, a reminder of her homeland. Slowly, America starts to feel more like home to her, and she begins to see the things she once found strange as familiar. With renewed determination, she decides to give the test another try, confident that she will succeed this time. The story ends on a hopeful note, with the girl embracing her new surroundings and feeling a sense of belonging in her adopted country.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it helps the readers understand that Saeng is determined to not give up despite facing setbacks. Her mother's support and understanding give her the strength to try again and face her fears. With a renewed sense of hope and determination, Saeng is ready to retake the test and overcome the challenges that come her way. The plant serves as a symbol of resilience and perseverance, reminding Saeng of her roots and giving her the courage to move forward. Ultimately, the story conveys a message of resilience, determination, and the importance of never giving up on one's dreams.

As the geese flew away, the young boy felt a pang of sadness in his heart. He knew that they would return again next year, but the thought of them leaving still made him feel a sense of loss. He watched them disappear into the horizon, their honking fading away with the distance.   He made a mental note to take note of their arrival next year and observe their behavior closely. Perhaps by understanding their patterns and habits, he could learn more about these magnificent creatures. The boy eagerly anticipated their return, knowing that each year would bring new opportunities to witness the beauty of nature up close.   In the meantime, he decided to focus on his studies and continue to explore the world around him. The geese may have left for now, but their presence had left a lasting impact on him. And as he looked up at the sky, he knew that their journey was far from over. The geese would return, and he would be waiting, ready to welcome them back with open arms.
The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when everything starts coming back she will take the test. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show a sense of determination that Saeng possesses. Saeng's journey towards acceptance and resilience is highlighted through her growing understanding of her new environment and her ability to find comfort and familiarity even in the midst of change.

She had to take a test but failed it, feeling disheartened as she left the testing center. On her way home, she passed by a flower shop and decided to treat herself to a plant that caught her eye. Come spring, she felt confident that she too would bloom, embracing the challenges and opportunities that lay ahead.

Change and disappointment can be overwhelming for some people, especially when they come all at once. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the ending includes the hibiscus budding and retaking the test to make a connection between the two. In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes with an odd ending. "When they come back," Saeng vowed silently to herself, "in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding, then I will take that test again." This signifies Saeng's willingness to adapt to the new country, as failing her driver's test symbolized her struggle to accept the change. By vowing to try again, she shows her determination to give the country another chance. "She found she was still too shaky to say the words at home..." indicates that Saeng still holds onto her past and hasn't fully embraced the new place as her home yet. This suggests that she is in a transitional phase, trying to find her place in the unfamiliar surroundings.

Saeng was disappointed when she failed the first time, but she didn't let that stop her. Instead of giving up, she decided to try again. With determination in her heart, she knew that she wouldn't let one setback define her. Saeng was resilient and refused to be held back by fear of failure. She understood that success often comes after facing challenges and obstacles. Saeng was ready to persevere and keep pushing forward, no matter what hurdles came her way. Failure was just a temporary setback for her, not the end of her journey. Saeng's story was far from over; she was determined to keep pursuing her dreams until she succeeded.

The last sentence of the story, "I will take that test again," highlights the girl's strong determination to succeed. This determination emphasizes the theme of new beginnings, as she plans to retake the test in the spring, symbolizing a fresh start in her life. This ending leaves the reader with a sense of hope and resilience, showcasing the protagonist's unwavering spirit in the face of challenges.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" made a good choice to conclude the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This paragraph hints to the reader that Saeng intends to combine her new and old lives. Her old life is represented by the hibiscus; she used to the constants from back home. The geese symbolize her new life; they have become "almost familiar to her now." The obstacle she faces is passing the driving test. The author implies that in the spring, when the old and new parts of Saeng's life are combined, Saeng will be able to overcome her "obstacle," and all will be well. With the geese in the ground, Saeng's life will have come full circle. In this way, the author effectively ties together the themes of change, adaptation, and growth in Saeng's journey, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and resolution for her future.

The geese flew in perfect formation, their sleek bodies cutting through the crisp morning air. Their feathers glistened in the sunlight, showcasing shades of grey and white that blended seamlessly together. As they honked in unison, their synchronized movements were a sight to behold.  Looking at the geese, one couldn't help but admire their beauty and grace. Each bird seemed to know its place in the group, playing a crucial role in maintaining the formation. It was a testament to their unity and teamwork, qualities that we as humans could certainly learn from.  In many ways, the geese's journey mirrored our own lives. Just like them, we too face challenges and obstacles along the way. But by working together and supporting one another, we can overcome these hardships and achieve great things.  So, the next time you see a flock of geese flying overhead, take a moment to appreciate their beauty and resilience. And remember, we are all like those geese - stronger together than we could ever be alone.

Minfong Ho ended her story "Winter Hibiscus" with an optimistic sentence because the main character, Saeng, was beginning to lose hope. Saeng decided to retake the driving test when her hibiscus flower was blooming, reminding her of her past life in Vietnam with her grandmother. "Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb." She preferred her life in Vietnam to her current one. She was going to wait until "this hibiscus is budding," so she could feel more comfortable and happy. The author wanted to end the story on a positive note, ensuring Saeng's happiness as she reconnects with her past and finds solace in the blooming hibiscus.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph in order to develop the theme and to project what the main character will do after she plants the hibiscus. This shows how Saeng is willing to adapt and persevere in the face of challenges, embodying the theme of adjusting to changes in life.

During "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng and her mother moved to a new place, and Saeng was struggling to adjust. Through this experience, Saeng learned to respect herself and believe in her abilities, setting the stage for a hopeful future.

"Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, is a story about transition to a new place and finding strength within oneself. Saeng, who had failed her driving test, felt disheartened as she made her way home. However, her spirits were lifted when she came across a plant in a florist shop that reminded her of home. This plant stirred memories of her homeland, prompting her to plant it at home and resolve to retake the driving test. When the geese returned, the plant served as a symbol of encouragement for Saeng, reminding her of her determination to succeed. The Winter Hibiscus not only brought a piece of her past to her new surroundings but also served as a source of inspiration for her future endeavors.

I got used to the rhythm of nature and the cycle of life. I found comfort in the repetition of the seasons, the blooming of flowers, and the falling of leaves. I will embrace the familiar and find peace in the continuity of life.

Winter Hibiscus by @CAPS1 Ho explores one's quest for acceptance and adaptation to changes in life. Saeng, the young protagonist, is struggling with her recent move to America from her homeland in Asia. After failing a test, Saeng impulsively spends a large amount of money on a flower. When she confides in her mother, Saeng silently vows something to herself. Saeng vows "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This ending perfectly captures the theme of adaptation as Saeng, in her own way, shows acceptance of her new home in America while still holding onto memories of her homeland. It signifies her determination to embrace change and move forward in her new environment, showcasing a resilient and adaptable spirit.

The author concludes this paragraph in the article because Ron is deeply attached to the plant, using it as a clock to determine when she can take the driver's test. For non-U.S. citizens, the opportunity to take the test only comes once a year.

Saeng, feeling dejected after failing her driving test, believed that she would not be able to transition smoothly to a new country as she searched for her past. However, as she found solace in plants, memories of Vietnam flooded back, causing her deep sorrow. The pain was so intense that it brought tears to her eyes. She longed for her homeland, her grandmother, and the life she had left behind. When she returned home to her mother with a plant, the cost disappointed her mother, but she understood the significance of the gesture. As Saeng observed the resilience of the hibiscus plant she had brought, she made a promise to herself that when it bloomed, she would try the driving test again. And so, with a newfound determination fueled by the symbolism of the blossoming plant, Saeng prepared to face her fears and embrace the challenges ahead.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author ends the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This signifies that the hibiscus, a plant reminding her of her home, can overcome the harsh winter just as she can overcome her current challenges. The flowers serve as a connection to her past and help her feel less alone, as seen when she experiences a wave of deep loss. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the decision to end the story with Saeng vowing to take the test again when the snows melt and the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, signifies her determination to overcome disappointment and adjust to life in a new country. In that moment, she feels a deep connection to the hibiscus, a symbol of her own journey of adaptation and growth in her new surroundings.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, the author's final paragraph highlights the significance of the hibiscus in the protagonist's journey. The hibiscus symbolizes resilience and strength, mirroring the girl's own inner fortitude needed to pass her driving test. Placing this paragraph at the end underscores the message that just as the hibiscus can bloom again after winter, so too can the girl overcome her challenges and emerge victorious. Through this use of symbolism, the author conveys a powerful message of hope and perseverance, inspiring readers to face their own obstacles with courage and determination.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with Saeng vowing to herself to take the test again in the spring when the hibiscus is budding. This shows that she is determined to fight for what is right and what she believes in.

Saeng wanted to show that she was strong and determined. She wanted to make the best of things with what she had. She had lost a lot of hope with the big move to another country. Its delicate petals symbolized her own resilience and beauty, even in the face of challenges. As the days grew longer and the air warmer, Saeng felt a renewed sense of hope and determination. Saeng was feeling nervous as she sat in the driver's seat, waiting for the examiner to start the test. She took a deep breath and reminded herself of all the hours she had spent practicing with her driving instructor. As the examiner got into the car and gave her instructions, Saeng felt a sense of calm wash over her. She carefully checked her mirrors, adjusted her seat, and confidently started the engine. As she smoothly navigated through the streets, confidently signaling at every turn, Saeng felt a sense of pride welling up inside her. When the test was finally over, the examiner turned to her and said, "Congratulations, you've passed." Saeng beamed with joy, knowing that all her hard work and determination had paid off. She had overcome her nerves and proved to herself that she was capable of achieving anything she set her mind to.

The hibiscus stood alone in the yard, its vivid red petals a stark contrast against the melting snow. As the geese returned overhead, honking in the distance, the hibiscus began to bud, a symbol of resilience and renewal in the changing seasons. It was a solitary figure in the landscape, yet it held its own beauty and strength, a reminder that even in isolation, life continues to thrive and bloom. And as the snow slowly melted away, revealing the promise of spring, the hibiscus stood tall and proud, a testament to the enduring power of nature.

Saeng watched as the leaves turned from vibrant greens to fiery reds and oranges, signaling the arrival of winter. She couldn't help but feel a sense of melancholy as the days grew shorter and the air turned colder. Knowing that she would have to wait until spring to see the vibrant colors return once again made her heart heavy. But she also knew that with winter came a time of rest and reflection, a time to prepare for the new growth that would come with the arrival of spring. And so, she embraced the changing seasons, finding beauty in the cycle of life and nature.

This simple declaration held a deeper meaning for Saeng - a promise to herself to not give up, to try again despite any setbacks. Just like the changing seasons bring new opportunities, she understood that failure is not the end but a chance to learn and grow. With determination in her heart, Saeng embraced the idea that with each new beginning comes the possibility of success, no matter how many times she may have to try.

She concludes that paragraph with the story because she really wants the people to realize that she is always having fun and loves where she is at. She is making her mark in the world and enjoys watching the flowers bloom, the geese return, and the hibiscus budding. These activities showcase her love for flowers and nature, which bring her immense joy and contentment.

Saeng, feeling a deep longing for her homeland, decided to return after many years of being away. With a heart full of hope and anticipation, Saeng set off on her journey back home, eager to rediscover the essence of her identity and the sense of belonging that had always eluded her in distant lands. As she embarked on this new chapter in her life, she carried with her the lessons learned and experiences gained, ready to confront whatever the future held with courage and determination. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng fails her driver's test and on her way home, she notices a flower that reminds her of her homeland. She purchases the flower and plants it in the garden with her mother. As they admire the newly planted flower, a flock of geese flies overhead, bringing a sense of familiarity to Saeng in her new surroundings. She realizes that despite feeling like a stranger at first, she is now finding her place. Saeng decides to take the driver's test again when the geese return in the spring. By then, the hibiscus will be blooming, symbolizing her growth and adaptation to her new environment. Saeng will be ready for the test, just as the geese are ready to come home and the hibiscus is ready to bloom.

The author includes this comparison to the plant because they believe that just like the plant, the character's confidence will also bloom with time. This signifies a sense of growth and development in the character's journey. By concluding the story with this paragraph, the author adds a deeper layer of meaning to the narrative, suggesting that growth and renewal are inevitable aspects of life. Just as the plant eventually blooms, so too will the character find their confidence restored and flourish once again.

As the sun set behind the mountains, casting a warm glow over the small town, Sarah knew that her life would never be the same. With her heart pounding, she made her way to the old abandoned house on the edge of town, the key clutched tightly in her hand. Sarah's eyes widened in astonishment as she realized the significance of what she had uncovered. This was only the beginning of an adventure that would take her on a journey beyond her wildest dreams. What other secrets lay waiting to be discovered? Only time would tell, but one thing was for certain - Sarah's life would never be ordinary again.

Saeng failed her driver's test, but as she stood by the hibiscus plant, memories of her old home flooded back. The vibrant flowers reminded her of the place she had left behind. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it explains that Saeng will try again once spring comes around. The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî ends the story with this paragraph because it reveals the importance of the Winter Hibiscus. In the story Saeng moves from Vietnam and feels very homesick. The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that was how he wanted the story to end. People have to adapt to different cultures if they move. They could do this in a variety of ways, including making new friends and adjusting to the area. However, when adjusting to a new area, you should still remember your past home as well. This is what Minfong Ho is trying to display in the ending paragraph of the story, "Winter Hibiscus". In the story, a teenage girl named Saeng moved from Vietnam to the United States. She has various remembrances of her past home while visiting a plant store. She buys a plant that was common in Vietnam and plants it in her garden. The last paragraph of the story says "In the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that driving test again". This shows Saeng's desire to fit in with this culture, by taking the driving test, as well as remember her past, by keeping the flower. This last paragraph summarizes Saeng's emotion for her old country as well as her determination to succeed here.

Because she was promising herself that when spring comes back, then she will take the driver's test again, she had set her sights on a specific goal. With the arrival of spring, she knew it was time to conquer her fears and doubts about driving. The promise she made to herself was a commitment to face the challenge head-on and prove to herself that she could pass the test. As the flowers began to bloom and the weather warmed up, she felt a renewed sense of determination and motivation. Spring symbolized a fresh start and a new beginning, giving her the courage to pursue her goal with confidence. With each passing day, she prepared diligently, studying the rules of the road and practicing her driving skills. Finally, when the day of the test arrived, she felt ready and composed. As she sat behind the wheel, she took a deep breath and remembered the promise she had made to herself. With focus and determination, she successfully completed the test, fulfilling her commitment and proving to herself that she was capable of achieving her goals. Spring had indeed brought not only new beginnings but also a sense of accomplishment and empowerment.

By saying she'll do the test again, it shows that she doesn't want to let this defeat her in her new home and her new life. She is determined to overcome her homesickness and make new memories in her current surroundings.

The author concludes Saeng's journey in the story by highlighting her vow to overcome obstacles. Despite feeling like a failure after failing her driving test, Saeng finds courage in her hibiscus plant, symbolizing resilience. The geese in the story represent the importance of perseverance and never giving up, inspiring Saeng to keep trying her hardest to succeed. The author concludes the story with this because the girl in the story is almost like the flower itself. When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. For many good reasons. There are many reasons the narrator could have ended with this paragraph. One reason it's the start of the winter so hibiscus won't return until spring. Saeng, feeling disheartened after failing her driving test, found solace in the Hibiscus plant that reminded her of the past. Her mother's words about the Hibiscus being strong enough to survive the cold months resonated with Saeng, filling her with a renewed sense of determination. As she envisioned the Hibiscus blooming in the spring, Saeng made a firm decision to persevere and pass her driving test. The sight of the Hibiscus served as a powerful symbol of resilience and hope, inspiring Saeng to overcome her challenges and strive for success. Just like the Hibiscus, she too would weather the storm and emerge stronger on the other side.

Saeng, it's time to make a change. You have a lot of potential, but you need to focus on your school work more and not just on gardening. Your mother is right to be concerned about your grades. At the end of the short story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng expresses her determination to retake her driver's test in the spring. Saeng felt her heart sink as she looked down at the test paper in front of her. She had failed. The weight of her disappointment was heavy, so heavy that she couldn't even bring herself to meet her mother's gaze.   Feeling the need to make amends, Saeng decided to buy a flower for her mother on the way home. As she handed the delicate bloom to her mother, a sense of hope began to bloom within her. Maybe this setback was just a temporary hurdle on her path to a brighter future in her new country.   As her mother accepted the flower with a soft smile, Saeng felt a glimmer of optimism. She knew that with perseverance and hard work, she could overcome any challenge that came her way. And with her mother's unwavering support, she felt confident that she would eventually succeed in her journey towards citizenship.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story in a well-mannered fashion. In "Hibiscus" by the author, the last paragraph is chosen because it aligns with the overall tone, hope, and representation of the essay. The tone throughout the story is one of sadness and disappointment, as the protagonist fails her driver's test and is overwhelmed by memories of her homeland when she sees a winter hibiscus. The plant serves as a poignant reminder of her past, making her yearn for the familiarity of Vietnam. As she reflects on the changes she has experienced over time, she realizes that what once seemed strange has now become familiar through the passage of seasons. The winter hibiscus triggers a deep emotional response in Saeng, leading her to tears and making it difficult for her to even utter the word "home" without breaking down. Despite the overwhelming emotions evoked by the plant, the final paragraph hints at a glimmer of hope as Saeng looks towards the coming spring and the possibility of trying again. This sense of renewed hope and resilience in the face of adversity ties back to the themes of the essay, making the last paragraph a fitting conclusion to the story.

This was a very interesting story that depicted all the hardships the young girl, Saeng, had gone through. The comparison of her hardships to the harsh winter, and the eventual melting away of the snow, symbolized a brighter future ahead. Despite the challenges she faced, there was a sense of optimism and resilience in Saeng's journey. The author did a great job of conveying the message that even in the darkest times, there is always the possibility of a new beginning, just like the blossoming of flowers in spring.

In the story, Saeng purchases a hibiscus plant as a way to hold on to her memories of her old home. Saeng's decision to retake the test in the spring further demonstrates her resilience and refusal to give up, highlighting her optimism for the future. Ultimately, the hibiscus plant serves as a reminder that while change may be inevitable, it is possible to find ways to hold on to what is important and make a new place feel like home.

Saeng vowed silently to herself that in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, she would retake the test. Her mother, focused on the plants, brushed the green fragments off Saeng's hands without a word. Saeng carefully planted the 'winter hibiscus,' her mind drifting to images of geese. Saeng watched as her mother carefully planted the winter hibiscus outside their house. The vibrant red flowers brought back memories of her childhood in Thailand, where these flowers bloomed abundantly. As she looked at the plant, Saeng couldn't help but see a reflection of herself. Just like the winter hibiscus, she was in a new environment, trying to take root and grow.  Saeng had recently moved to America and was struggling to adjust to the new language and culture. She had failed her English test, but she was determined to try again. Just like the plant needed time to adapt to its new surroundings, Saeng knew that she needed time to improve and succeed.  As the days passed, Saeng watered the plant diligently, watching it slowly grow and blossom. She saw herself in the plant, both of them facing challenges but determined to thrive. Saeng knew that just like the winter hibiscus, she would eventually find her place and flourish in her new home. The plant served as a reminder that growth takes time, but with patience and perseverance, success is possible. And as Saeng looked at the blooming flowers, she felt a renewed sense of hope and determination for her own journey ahead.

Saeng realized that many of the things she had once found strange had become familiar through the quiet repetition of seasons. She understood that her initial perceptions had evolved over time, leading to a newfound sense of comfort and understanding. Despite any challenges she may face, Saeng remained determined to continue trying the test again, confident in her ability to adapt and grow through experience.

Saeng took a deep breath, feeling the cool breeze brush against her face as she stood outside her new home. She glanced at the small garden she had lovingly tended to, the colorful flowers swaying gently in the wind. It was a stark contrast to the bustling city she had left behind. But somehow, in the midst of this serene setting, she found a sense of peace.  As she looked around, memories of her past life flooded back to her. The laughter of her friends, the warmth of her family, the taste of her favorite foods - they all seemed like distant echoes now. Yet, as she closed her eyes and took another deep breath, she realized that she was slowly getting used to her new surroundings.  With a newfound determination, Saeng made a silent promise to herself. She was going to try the test she had failed once again. She knew it wouldn't be easy, but she also knew that she had to keep moving forward. And as she took the first step towards her goal, she couldn't help but smile. For the first time since she had arrived, she felt like she belonged. And that was all the motivation she needed to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

Saeng failed her driving test, and it was a blow to her confidence. However, instead of giving up, she decided to start over and try again in the spring. She understood that everyone makes mistakes, and the important thing is to learn from them and keep moving forward. By renewing herself and her determination, Saeng believes she will be better prepared for her next attempt. This story conveys the message that it is never too late to begin again, even after setbacks or failures. With a fresh perspective and renewed effort, success is always within reach.

The author concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with a sentence about retaking the driver's test in the spring, to express the themes of adapting to circumstances and determination to succeed. Saeng's fascination with the changing seasons led her to closely observe the patterns of nature. As winter approached, she eagerly awaited the transformation that would unfold. When the season arrived, she carefully took note of the snow-covered landscapes, the bare branches of trees, and the frosty air that enveloped everything. Saeng's keen observation allowed her to anticipate the return of winter with a sense of familiarity and understanding. By committing these details to memory, she could relive the beauty of winter whenever she pleased, capturing the essence of the season in her mind. Saeng's connection to the cycle of nature brought her a profound sense of joy and wonder, reminding her of the ever-changing yet timeless rhythm of life.

As the snow continued to fall outside her window, Sarah couldn't help but feel a sense of longing for the warm days of summer. She watched as the hibiscus plant in her room bloomed brightly, its vibrant red petals a stark contrast to the white landscape beyond.  Sarah thought about how the hibiscus had adapted to its new environment, thriving despite the cold and darkness of winter. And she realized that, in a way, she was doing the same. She had come to this new society with uncertainty and fear, but as the days passed, she found herself slowly acclimating to her surroundings.  By the time winter ended and the first signs of spring appeared, Sarah knew that she too would have adapted, just like the hibiscus. She would have found her place in this new world, blooming brightly and embracing the changes that had come her way.  And as she looked out at the snow-covered landscape, Sarah felt a sense of peace knowing that, like the hibiscus, she too would thrive in her new home.

Saeng, the young girl from "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, moved from Vietnam to the United States with hopes of getting her driver's license. Despite failing the test, she finds solace in a hibiscus plant that reminds her of home. Her mother, initially worried about the cost, understands Saeng's homesickness and supports her purchase of the plant. As Saeng plants the hibiscus, she observes the geese, realizing how they change habitats yearly. Inspired by the geese and the budding hibiscus, Saeng makes a promise to herself that she will retake the test in the spring when the geese return and the hibiscus blooms. Through these symbols of nature, Saeng finds the courage and determination to try again, embracing the changes and challenges of her new life in the United States.

From her experience with the hibiscus, we can see that this plant really influences her because it reminds her so much of her old home. Also, we can see that everything and everybody should get a second chance. In her case, it is the test she wants to take again. So the hibiscus is good for her, something she can hold onto from her old home. It symbolizes hope and renewal, giving her the strength to face new challenges in her current surroundings.

A balanced diet is essential for maintaining good health and preventing diseases. It is important to include a variety of foods in your daily meals to ensure that you are getting all the necessary nutrients your body needs. This includes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats.   Fruits and vegetables are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help protect the body from illnesses. Whole grains provide fiber, which aids in digestion and helps you feel full longer. Lean proteins, such as poultry, fish, beans, and nuts, are important for building and repairing tissues in the body. Healthy fats, like those found in avocados, olive oil, and nuts, are essential for brain function and hormone production.   In addition to eating a variety of foods, it is also important to watch your portion sizes and limit your intake of sugar, salt, and unhealthy fats. Drinking plenty of water and staying physically active are also important components of a healthy lifestyle. By making small changes to your diet and lifestyle, you can improve your overall health and well-being. Remember, a healthy diet is not just about losing weight, but about nourishing your body and staying strong and healthy for years to come.

In stories, authors use different techniques to create various effects on the readers. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author chose to conclude the narrative with a paragraph that evokes a touching sentiment and ties together all the elements discussed throughout the story. The use of imagery, such as in the line "Saeng vowed silently to herself," paints a vivid picture of a solitary girl in a cold garden, adding an emotional depth to the scene. Additionally, the mention of hibiscus blooming when the geese return and the idea of retaking a test connect back to earlier points in the story, providing a sense of closure and completeness. Overall, the author's choice to end the story with this paragraph serves to evoke a poignant response from the readers and bring together the various themes explored in "Winter Hibiscus."

Feeling misunderstood and out of place in her new culture, Saeng is uncertain of her place. Saeng feels a deep sense of loss after leaving her grandmother behind. To fill this void, she purchases a hibiscus plant, reminiscent of her grandmother's comforting scent. Despite spending a significant amount on the plant, Saeng believes it is necessary for her to feel more connected to her roots. She reflects on the abruptness of leaving her country, feeling like it happened in the blink of an eye. Remembering her grandmother's strength, Saeng strives to be resilient and not succumb to tears when reminded of her past. As the hibiscus plant begins to bloom, she sees it as a symbol of growth and hopes to overcome her sadness. Saeng is determined to pass this emotional test and find solace in her memories of her grandmother, allowing herself to smile through the pain.

The reason I think that the author did it is because wanted you to know what time it took place and what the weather was like then it also so tells you how long she is going to wait like till the snow melts and that is going to be while and when the geese live and return home so this is why I think she tells you what is like. I think that this is about winter hibiscus and hedge tall and lush bad surrounded their garden its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers, She said when she got to the hibiscus she reached out and touched a petal gently. The reason that the author had ended the story the way she did was to leave the reader on the last thought. Also it symbolizes rebirth. When Saeng says, "... this hibiscus is budding ..." The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wants there to be hope for the future seeing that hibiscus budding in the spring is what Saeng is waiting for. As the sun set behind the mountains, casting a warm glow over the landscape, the weary travelers finally reached their destination. They had faced many challenges along the way, but their determination had carried them through. As they looked out at the breathtaking view before them, a sense of accomplishment washed over them. Despite the obstacles, they had made it. And in that moment, they knew that their journey had been worth every step. The beauty of the world stretched out before them, a reminder of the endless possibilities that awaited those willing to embark on the path less traveled. And as they stood there, basking in the fading light of the day, they knew that this was only the beginning of their adventures.

Saeng is determined to carry on her mother's gardening legacy, ensuring that the traditions and practices she learned from her elders are not forgotten. By nurturing the same flowers and plants her mother once tended to, Saeng is not only preserving a piece of her family's history but also finding solace and connection to her roots. The garden serves as a living tribute to her mother, a place where memories bloom alongside the blossoms. Through her dedication to the garden, Saeng keeps her mother's spirit alive, embodying the love and care that was once bestowed upon her. With each seed planted and each flower bloomed, Saeng honors the past while creating a vibrant and flourishing future.

I believe that the author ended the story with this paragraph to show the persistence of the main character. The author concludes the story with the paragraph because she wants to do it right next time. She realizes that she can try every year to get it right and impress her mother. This determination to improve and make her mother proud drives her to keep striving for perfection. Through her ongoing efforts, she hopes to eventually succeed in her goal and create a lasting impact on her mother.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author likely ends the story with the quote because she wants to show that Saeng thinks of the Hibiscus as more than just a flower; to her, it is also a memory. For Saeng, the Winter Hibiscus is like storybooks, waiting to be read simply by smelling the flower. By keeping the hibiscus in her garden, she can have a beautiful reminder of where she came from. The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. For example, it shows a sense of hope, when she says "this hibiscus is budding". That indicates a new beginning or starting over. The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph for a number of reasons. The last paragraph states that ìwhen they come back ... I will take the test again,î (Ho @NUM1). The author cherished the flowers, finding solace in their beauty. When she did not pass her driving test, she felt disheartened, but the presence of the flowers uplifted her spirits. As the snow begins to melt, she eagerly awaits the arrival of spring, knowing that the flowers will bloom once again. With renewed faith, she is determined to retake the test and persevere until she succeeds. The flowers symbolize hope and resilience, motivating her to keep moving forward despite setbacks. In the cycle of seasons, she finds comfort and strength, ready to face whatever challenges come her way.

The author concluded this sentence because he was letting everyone know that Saeng would return to the hibiscus and take care of it still, and that she has not forgotten about it. Saeng's dedication to the hibiscus plant was unwavering, and she made a promise to herself to always nurture and cherish it. Despite the passing of time and the busyness of life, Saeng remained committed to the well-being of the hibiscus, ensuring that it continued to thrive under her care. This small act of tending to the plant symbolized Saeng's enduring love and connection to nature, a bond that would never fade.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", by Minfong Ho, a teenager, Saeng, moves from Vietnam to the United States. She later takes a driver's test but does not succeed in passing, finding comfort in her memories of her homeland. The last paragraph states "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. Saeng was upset about failing her test and was reminded of her homeland and the changes she has had to adapt to during this move. The hibiscus plant gives Saeng hope to continue her journey even when things get very hard. The end of winter gives both the plant and Saeng a chance to start over and a renewed hope to begin again. Saeng will find it easier to get through hardships if she continues to find comfort from her past.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to get the readers wondering. To show that sheís not going to give up on what she wants to do. She knows that the journey ahead will be challenging, but she is determined to overcome any obstacles in her way. With a strong sense of purpose and a clear vision of her goals, she is ready to face whatever may come her way. The author's unwavering commitment to her dreams is evident in her resolute tone, leaving readers inspired to pursue their own aspirations with the same level of determination and perseverance. The story may have ended, but her journey is far from over.

The author Minfong Ho ends the story by reflecting on the test Saeng failed and her determination to retake it. The test symbolized a new beginning for Saeng, a chance to move forward and leave behind the past. Despite her initial attachment to the memories associated with a flower she purchased, Saeng eventually realizes that she can embrace both her old and new life. By vowing to try again and please both herself and her mother, Saeng demonstrates her willingness to start afresh and embark on a new chapter in her life.

Saeng realized that she needed to take a step back and give herself some time to prepare for the test. By acknowledging her need for a break and focusing on what she needed to do, she knew that she could improve her chances of passing. Taking the time to rest and study effectively would give her the opportunity to succeed. With a clear mind and dedication to her goals, Saeng was confident that she could overcome the challenges ahead and achieve her desired outcome.

Saeng's determination is further highlighted when she refuses to give up on her passion for plants, despite her mother's disapproval. She is willing to go to great lengths to recreate the beauty of her previous garden, even if it means spending a significant amount of money. This demonstrates her unwavering commitment to her goals and her resilience in the face of obstacles. Despite the challenges she faces in adapting to her new lifestyle, Saeng's determination and perseverance will undoubtedly lead her to success in the end.

When the hibiscus is budding and a new season starts, Saeng will be a new person and will be able to take the test. The cold snow, fleeing geese, and planted hibiscus all symbolize Saeng's current state of being - feeling cold, wanting to escape, and being restricted. However, as the geese return and the hibiscus grows freely, Saeng will also mature and be ready to face the challenges ahead. Like the hibiscus, she too will bloom and thrive in the new season, ready to conquer whatever comes her way.

The author ends the story with the sentence provided because she was looking forward to the time when winter would be over and she could test her gardening skills with the plants she had carefully planted.

Saeng decided to wait for the perfect moment to retake the test. She wanted to wait until the snow had melted, the geese had returned, and the hibiscus was budding. She knew that she needed more time to prepare herself mentally and emotionally for the challenge ahead. When the time came, Saeng would be ready to face the test once again. Patience and perseverance were key, and she was determined to succeed when the right moment arrived. Until then, she would continue to study and improve, knowing that her hard work would eventually pay off.

Because when the hibiscus started budding, it will give her inspiration to try and pass the test again. Therefore, this is the reason the author concludes the story with the last paragraph. The hibiscus, with its vibrant blooms and familiar scent, represented a piece of her past and a source of strength for the challenges ahead. It was a reminder of where she came from and a symbol of resilience and determination. With the hibiscus by her side, she felt ready to face whatever obstacles came her way, knowing that she carried the spirit of home within her. The narrator took the test again, feeling a sense of determination despite the disappointment of not being in her old home. When she realized the hibiscus was different from what she was used to, a wave of nostalgia washed over her. She missed the familiarity of her past life. However, instead of giving up, she decided to embrace her new surroundings and make the best of it. As the geese flew back and the hibiscus began to bloom, she made a promise to herself to keep trying, to adapt, and to never lose sight of her goals. The author's message was clear - perseverance and resilience are key in facing challenges, and the narrator embodied this spirit as she moved forward in her new home.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the protagonist's growth and development throughout the narrative. By reflecting on past experiences and acknowledging the impact of their choices, the protagonist demonstrates a newfound sense of self-awareness and maturity. This conclusion serves to tie up loose ends and provide a sense of closure for both the character and the reader, leaving them with a sense of resolution and satisfaction. Overall, the final paragraph effectively encapsulates the themes of the story and leaves a lasting impression on the audience.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he knows that he messed up on the test and he is saying that when spring comes back around, he will be ready to take the test. When she moved to America, she saw all the beautiful flowers that were out in the spring. She saw a blossom that caught her attention - it was called hibiscus. She felt a connection to it, as back where she came from, they grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in her grandmother's walls. The blossom reminded her of her grandmother with her long gray hair freshly washed. She decided to visit the florist to see if they had the hibiscus, hoping to bring a piece of her past into her new home in America.

In the passage "Winter Hibiscus" by Monfong Ho, the quote "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again" symbolizes Saeng's new journey in the new country she lives in. In the test, Saeng is having a personal discrepancy, missing her homeland as she states "I failed the test." This test meant more to her than just failing. It was a test of her ability to function in her new country and she failed. The "when they came back..." quote can be analyzed deeply as the snow being her obstacles and the hibiscus being herself. When the obstacles melt away and she buds into a new, stronger person, she will take the test again.

She will go back to where she started, completing the circle of her journey. The familiar sights and sounds will greet her once again, marking the passage of time. Each year, she finds herself back at the beginning, ready to embark on a new adventure. The cycle continues, offering her the chance to reflect on the growth and changes that have occurred since she last stood in this place. As she embraces the familiar surroundings, she knows that she is exactly where she is meant to be, ready to start anew.

In today's fast-paced world, it is essential to stay informed and up-to-date with current events. Whether it be through traditional news sources such as newspapers and television or modern platforms like social media and news websites, being aware of what is happening around us is crucial. By staying informed, we can make better decisions, engage in meaningful conversations, and be prepared for any challenges that may come our way.  One of the key benefits of staying informed is the ability to make informed decisions. When we are aware of the latest developments in politics, economics, and society, we can make better choices that align with our values and goals. For example, staying updated on the stock market can help us make wise investment decisions, while following political news can aid us in voting for the right candidates.  Furthermore, staying informed allows us to engage in meaningful conversations with others. By being aware of current events, we can contribute to discussions and debates on important issues. This not only helps us broaden our perspectives but also enables us to learn from others and grow intellectually.  Lastly, staying informed prepares us for any challenges that may come our way. Whether it be a natural disaster, a public health crisis, or a major policy change, being informed allows us to anticipate and respond effectively to unexpected events. This can help us protect ourselves and our loved ones, as well as navigate through difficult situations with resilience and confidence.  In conclusion, staying informed is crucial in today's world for making informed decisions, engaging in meaningful conversations, and being prepared for any challenges that may arise. By staying updated on current events, we can lead more fulfilling and successful lives, both personally and professionally.

Everything in the story is about to change. The winter will change to spring, the snow will melt and vanish, the geese will return, the hibiscus will bud, Saeng will also change and mature as well. Saeng is just like the hibiscus plant, out of place on the road in the new country, and she must adapt like the hibiscus plant. For example, Saeng observed how different the plant looked in the shop window than it did in her home country. She was observing herself and how different she appeared as well. The reason for putting the paragraph at the very end was to show that she had matured already and putting it at the end to show that she had grown. Putting it at the beginning would not give the same effect. The hibiscus plant was able to sustain the harsh winters change. The author concludes the story with the paragraph shown for several reasons. First, the author needs to conclude the story without leaving any questions in the readers mind as to what happens. This is achieved by incorporating the geese, hibiscus, and her driver's test into the last paragraph. Next, this last paragraph adds a theme of perseverance to the story. The main character is driven to take the driver's test again through memories of Vietnam. Lastly, it adds to the character by saying that she will "take that test again", she is shown as being realistic and not overly consistent. These are some of the ways that the last paragraph enhances the story.  The next morning, as the sun rose over the horizon, she watched the geese fly overhead, their honking filling the air. The hibiscus in her garden bloomed brightly, a symbol of resilience and strength. She took a deep breath, feeling determined. "I will take that test again," she thought to herself. And with that thought, she knew that no matter what challenges lay ahead, she would face them head-on, just like she had done before. And as she walked back into her house, a sense of peace washed over her, knowing that she was ready for whatever the future held.

Saeng felt a pang of nostalgia as she caught sight of the hibiscus plant outside her window, its vibrant red blooms reminding her of home. Despite the twinge of longing for her homeland, she also felt a sense of comfort as she watched the familiar sight of the geese flying overhead. She knew that she was slowly adjusting to her new surroundings, finding solace in the small connections she made with the nature around her. As she contemplated retaking the driving test, she realized that she had the power to decide her own path, just like the geese following their migration patterns. Saeng was determined to embrace this new chapter of her life with resilience and optimism, knowing that she would always carry a piece of her past with her wherever she went.

Saeng took a deep breath and looked around at the unfamiliar surroundings. She felt a wave of anxiety wash over her as she realized she was not prepared for this test. However, as she walked further into the garden, she noticed some plants that reminded her of home. The sight of the familiar flowers brought her comfort, and she remembered that spring was just around the corner - a time when these plants would bloom beautifully. With renewed determination, Saeng knew that she would be ready to face the test again when the time came.

In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," a young girl from Vietnam moves to a new location and fails the driver's test. Feeling homesick, she decides to purchase a winter hibiscus plant to remind her of her homeland. As she waits for the snow to melt and the geese to return in the spring, she plans to take the driver's test again. The symbolism of the hibiscus blooming represents her readiness to try once more. She believes that just like the geese returning home and the hibiscus blossoming, she too will be prepared to face the challenge again. This connection to nature gives her hope and strength to persevere, reflecting her deep emotional ties to her roots and determination to succeed.

In the story "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, Saeng faces obstacles as she adjusts to a new country. After failing her driving test, she is reminded of her homeland by tropical flowers. This moment symbolizes Saeng's growth and determination to adapt to her new environment, mirroring the changing seasons and the resilience of nature. It shows her commitment to not giving up and her willingness to embrace change, just like the geese returning to a transformed landscape and the hibiscus blossoming into a beautiful flower. In this way, the author ties together the themes of growth and change, emphasizing the resilience and beauty of nature. As the geese disappeared into the distance, Sarah noticed the first signs of spring - delicate flowers blooming in the meadow. It was a beautiful reminder that life goes on, even in the face of loss. And as Sarah stood there, surrounded by nature's beauty, she found solace in the thought that her grandma's spirit was soaring with the geese, free and at peace.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî included the last paragraph to convey to readers that she will be moving on, but still remembering her old country. Before finding the flower, the author terribly missed her old country. "Itís-itís not a real one, ëSaeng mumbled. 'I mean not like the kind we had at-atí she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, last she burst into tears again." She missed her home in the other country and was having trouble getting past it. The author could not accept her new country as home yet. Saeng, the hibiscus flower brought back memories of her old country, making it even more difficult to move on.î One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmotherís long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb." The flower was too much of a memory. She finally had something from home that she could hold. ìGently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold onto.î The author now had a solid thing to remind her of home. This was the first step to finally moving on. Now Saeng needed some time to get use to her new country. ìAlmost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.î Saeng needed just a little more time, almost like a hibernation. She decided once the hibiscus came out of hibernation, and was ready to bloom, she would be ready to accept her new country and move on. Saeng decide the time between fail and spring would be long enough to adjust to her new life. By taking the test, Saeng will be moving on. The author included this last paragraph so that readers can infer that Saeng will take the last steps towards acceptance of her new country and move on by taking the test, although she will look back on her old country through the winter hibiscus. Saeng was on the verge of fully embracing her new life and leaving the past behind, with the winter hibiscus serving as a gentle reminder of where she came from, as she finally takes the next step forward in her journey.

The story includes this paragraph because at the very beginning of the story, the girl failed the test. When she told her mother, she saw that her mother was upset with it. So after they planted the plant, she decided to take the test over, knowing that her mother would think the best of it. Also, it is in there because the story started out with her telling her mother that she failed the test. If you kept it out, people who read it would be like, "Ok, so her mother just let her fail the test and didn’t do anything about it." Plus, when the reader reads that the girl failed the test, they are going to be wanting to know if she took it again and why she took it again if she did. This paragraph adds depth to the story and sets up the narrative for the girl's journey to retake the test and prove herself.

The author chose to end the story in an unconcluded manner, leaving readers hanging and eager for more. This strategy is often used to maintain reader interest and potentially pave the way for a sequel. By not tying up all loose ends, the author keeps the door open for further development of the plot and characters in future works. This type of ending can be frustrating for some readers, but it also serves as a hook to draw them into the author's other books, where they may find the answers they seek. Ultimately, the unconcluded ending adds an element of mystery and anticipation, enticing readers to continue following the author's literary journey.

Saeng fails the test because, though she buys a beautiful plant it is much too expensive. "But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn't cost that much!" Saeng becomes very upset and realizes that she has failed her mother. Saeng still plants the winter hibiscus in the ground. "Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the 'winter hibiscus' into it." This shows that even though she had failed she wasn't going to give up on the hibiscus because it represented her home. It was very special to her.

The Author concludes the with paragraph because she wants to emphasize the importance of taking action in addressing climate change. Through her discussion of the various ways individuals, communities, and governments can contribute to mitigating the effects of climate change, she underscores the urgent need for collective efforts to protect the environment and ensure a sustainable future for generations to come. By highlighting the role that each one of us can play in making a difference, she inspires readers to take responsibility and make positive changes in their own lives. Ultimately, the Author's conclusion serves as a call to action, urging everyone to join the fight against climate change and work towards a healthier planet for all.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it shows that the character in the story is starting to adapt to her new country. In the beginning of the story the character "Saeng" is feeling homesick and has not adapted to her new country. She is on her way home from her driver's test, which she just failed, and on the way she spots a hibiscus in a flower shop. The hibiscus is special to her because it reminds her of her home country of Vietnam. For Saeng, the hibiscus represents comfort in times of disappointment, a connection to her past experiences, and the ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng has not adjusted to this change in her life, and it has affected her badly. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because he wanted to show the reader that there will always be changes and obstacles in your life, but there will always be something or someone that will help you overcome them. The author shows this by concluding the story with this paragraph and showing the reader that Saeng used the hibiscus as her way of overcoming, and when she is ready and she has adjusted, she will take her driving test again.

Saeng eagerly anticipated the end of winter and the arrival of spring, when the hibiscus flowers would begin to bloom once again. With the changing seasons, she saw the opportunity to start anew and try her hand at gardening once more. As she looked forward to planting her own little garden, filled with vibrant colors and new life, Saeng felt a sense of hope and renewal wash over her. The promise of the coming spring brought a sense of excitement and determination, inspiring her to begin afresh and embrace the beauty of nature that surrounded her.

This paragraph illustrates Saeng's determination to transform herself over the course of a year in preparation for retaking a test, akin to a rebirth. Through the flower's phases of death and renewal, Saeng sees the potential for her own personal growth and improvement. Just as the hibiscus opens up to reveal its beauty once again, Saeng aims to emerge from her own challenges as a better, more resilient individual.

The author concludes the story with ìin the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," a young girl named Saeng moves away from home and tries to adapt to her new lifestyle and changes. As she continues to adjust to her new life, Saeng's experiences with the winter hibiscus serve as a reminder of her own ability to bloom and flourish in any circumstances.

Saeng was determined to pass her driver's test. Just like the geese flying south for the winter, she would not rest until she achieved her goal. With grit and resilience, Saeng would continue to strive towards success, mirroring the relentless journey of the geese as they made their way to warmer climates. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by CAPS1 Ho, the author leaves the story off with a powerful ending. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by @CAPS1 Ho, a girl named Saeng failed her driver's test that day but vowed to retake it in the spring. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with a paragraph that conveys several important messages. The image of her mother working tirelessly in the garden serves as a reminder of the strength and perseverance that run in her family, motivating Saeng to continue pursuing her goals despite setbacks. As she watches her mother, she feels a renewed sense of purpose and readiness to tackle whatever obstacles come her way. And so, with the changing seasons and the support of her family, Saeng prepares herself for the next chapter in her journey towards success.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is showing that the hibiscus inspires her and gives comfort that no person could try and do. For example, after Saeng failed her drivers test, she was disappointed. On her way home she saw a hibiscus and went to a florist shop to try and buy it. Saeng took a peddle from the plant and held it tightly while she closed her eyes. The plant reminded her of her real home in Vietnam which she loved. The hibiscus became a form of comfort for Saeng since she had just failed her drivers test, even though the plant was not the same as the one at home. By the author ending the story with Saeng saying she will wait until the hibiscus starts budding to take the test again, it shows that the hibiscus helps her to overcome obstacles in life and it helps her to get through hardships she faces.
Saeng will retake the test during the season when these plants are thriving, allowing her to appreciate the plot, characters, and historical context surrounding them more deeply.

She is determined not to retake the test unless the winter hibiscus plants return. Her mother reassured her that the plants were resilient enough to survive the winter. Saeng silently promised herself that in the spring, as the snow melts and the geese return, and the hibiscus blooms once more, she will be ready to retake the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it symbolizes the hope that things will get better. The author concludes this story with this sentence, because it shows hope for the future. This sentence lets readers know that times are hard now, but in time things will get better. The snow had begun to melt, signaling the arrival of spring. As the winter frost receded, flowers, trees, and grass started to bloom once again, painting the landscape with vibrant colors. It was clear that winter was behind us, and the time had come to embrace the new season. The author mentioned planting in winter to ensure a beautiful growth in the spring, highlighting the importance of preparation for the changing seasons. With each passing day, nature transformed, displaying its beauty and resilience in the face of changing weather. Spring had officially arrived, bringing with it a sense of renewal and growth that could be seen all around.

I will take that test again," which relates to the determination of the hibiscus flower, which struggles persistently through the winter. Authors sometimes conclude a story with a certain paragraph describing an action that will take place in the future. This story about believing in yourself and never giving up was a tale of perseverance. Saeng remained steadfast in her belief that she could pass her driver's test, even though she faced disappointment in the end. However, she found solace in the hibiscus flower, which held great significance to her as a connection to her homeland and a symbol of beauty in a challenging time. Adapting to a new country can be difficult, and even the smallest setback can feel overwhelming. Like the hibiscus growing by the highway, Saeng felt a sense of helplessness and isolation. Despite her initial setback, Saeng vowed to retake her driver's test when the hibiscus bloomed in the spring. The hibiscus truly represents Saeng as a person, resilient and determined to overcome obstacles. As she waits for the hibiscus to bloom once again, Saeng remains hopeful and determined to succeed in her future endeavors.

Saeng found solace in nature after failing her driving test. She sought comfort in purchasing a plant, symbolizing hope and renewal. As she observed the geese leaving and the hibiscus beginning to bud, she felt a sense of reassurance. The cycle of nature reminded her that there will always be another opportunity to try again. With the return of the geese and the blooming of the hibiscus, Saeng found peace in the knowledge that she could attempt the driving test again next year. Nature's constant presence and rhythm provided her with the strength to face challenges with resilience and optimism.

As the sun set behind the mountains, Sarah knew that her journey was far from over. She had learned to embrace change and uncertainty, knowing that each season of life brings its own challenges and opportunities. With a heart full of hope and a spirit of resilience, she was ready to face whatever the future held, knowing that she would continue to bloom and grow, just like the flowers in her garden. And as she looked out at the twilight sky, she whispered to herself, "This is just the beginning."

At the end of the short story, "Winter Hibiscus," the writer Minfong Ho includes somewhat inspirational concluding sentence "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." Throughout the essay, Saeng is depressed she had to leave her homeland so hurriedly losing her childhood and beloved grandmother, "A blink, a changed switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone." as Saeng narrates in deeper detail. Also contributing to the feelings of sorrow in the story is how much Saeng cries remembering her tragic past. In both the greenhouse, recalling the events of her grandmother such as when she says, "Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's grey hair Saeng would help knot the hair the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it." and in the garden, when she talks to her mother and plants the flower. Saeng was eagerly awaiting the arrival of spring so that she could retake the test. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, Saeng, who recently moved to @LOCATION1 from Vietnam, returns home feeling dejected after failing her driver's test. She believes her failure reflects her inability to adapt to her new life, disappointing both her mother and herself. Trying to console her mother, Saeng buys a flower from Vietnam, a winter Hibiscus, which her mother begins to plant. Witnessing her mother's forgiveness through the act of planting the flower, Saeng realizes her own capacity to adapt to her new environment, just like the winter Hibiscus. Encouraged by this realization, she resolves to retake the driver's test in the spring. By ending the story with Saeng's promise to persevere and not give up, the author highlights her courage and determination to embrace change and overcome challenges.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is not giving up and she will take the test again. Despite facing setbacks, she remains determined to persevere and grow from the experience. This resilience and positive attitude will likely lead to future success and personal growth.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, a girl named Saeng is trying to adjust to a new life in a new location after coming from Vietnam. Bringing the plant home in a pot, Saeng reminisces about the memories she shared with similar plants back in Vietnam. Her mother joins her, sharing a moment of connection and comfort. Saeng feels a sense of solace. As she looks at the hibiscus plant, she silently vows to herself that when spring comes and the snow melts, she will take the drivers test again. The flower has given her the confidence to try again and move forward, holding onto her memories while overcoming her pain.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author chose to conclude the story the way she did to show the comfort the hibiscus provided that allowed Saeng to move on. The author is expressing hope for the future in her concluding paragraph. Although just failing her driver's test and adjusting to a new atmosphere, Saeng finds comfort in a Hibiscus. After all that had happened, it was clear to me that forgiveness was the only way to move forward. Holding onto anger and resentment would only continue to poison my heart and soul. By choosing to forgive, I was not excusing the actions of others or saying that what they did was okay. Instead, I was releasing myself from the burden of carrying around that negativity. I was choosing to let go of the past and open myself up to a future filled with peace and possibility. In the end, forgiveness was not a sign of weakness, but rather a symbol of strength and resilience. And as I stood there, feeling the weight of the world lift off my shoulders, I knew that I had made the right choice.

The "Winter Hibiscus" is a relatively sad, but hopeful story that uses lots of symbols. The author concluded the story with a confident ending that makes the reader feel satisfied. "Winter Hibiscus" ends with a hopeful tone thanks to the confident vow Saeng silently makes. She had a rough day, and the author wanted to make sure she had something to look as a goal. The second reason the author concluded with that conclusion paragraph was to relate some of the objects she sees to the spring. The geese represent the new place she is living in, and the hibiscus represents her old home. This paragraph links these two symbols together, so the reader can relate them to the spring. The way the author concluded the story was brilliantly done. It represents a hopeful tone, and symbols that relate to spring. It ends confidently, and leaves the reader satisfied.

Authors carefully select their closing paragraphs to convey specific meanings and themes. In this story, the character's mention of a budding hibiscus symbolizes overcoming obstacles, like retaking a failed test. The reference to melting snow and returning geese represents new beginnings and opportunities. By ending the story with these images, the author reinforces the message of resilience and the chance for redemption. The choice of the closing paragraph is crucial in delivering these powerful themes and leaving a lasting impact on the reader.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because of a saying that when it's cold and silent she's hot to herself but when the snow melts and spring is here, she's lively and vibrant. In the winter, she may feel introspective and reserved, but as the seasons change, she becomes more outgoing and engaged in various activities. This contrast highlights the transformative power of nature on her mood and behavior, showing how she adapts and thrives in different environments. The shift from winter to spring symbolizes a period of growth, renewal, and joy in her life, emphasizing the cyclical nature of change and the beauty of embracing each season with openness and positivity.

Saeng, like the geese and the hibiscus, will return again. The geese, with their predictable migration pattern, serve as a reminder of the cyclical nature of life. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by CAPS1 Ho, the narrator is drawn to a "winter" Hibiscus plant in a greenhouse, reminiscent of her homeland and memories of her grandmother. Authors use various techniques to enhance their stories, making them more engaging and impactful. This technique not only adds emotional weight to the story but also effectively conveys Saeng's determination and perseverance in the face of challenges. In doing so, the author creates a more compelling and memorable narrative that resonates with readers long after they have finished the story.

The short story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho ends with the main character Saeng making a promise to herself. The author uses heavy imagery and symbolism throughout the story, with the hibiscus in the floral shop symbolizing a connection to Saeng's homeland. The bitter melon, a fruit loved by Saeng but disliked by the people in @LOCATION1, represents her struggle to connect with others in her new environment. The budding hibiscus and returning geese symbolize a new opportunity for Saeng to pass her drivers test and better adapt to life in @LOCATION1. Saeng's determination to try again in the spring reflects her hope for a fresh start and a brighter future in her new home.
