Saeng's determination to succeed was unwavering as she carefully tended to the hibiscus plant in her small garden. Each day, she would lovingly water the plant and ensure it received plenty of sunlight. As the days passed, the hibiscus began to blossom, its vibrant petals a symbol of hope and perseverance for Saeng.  With each new bud that appeared, Saeng's confidence grew. She knew that just like the hibiscus, she too would bloom and flourish despite the setbacks she faced. The sight of the beautiful flowers served as a constant reminder that giving up was not an option.  When the day of her driving test arrived once again, Saeng approached it with a newfound sense of determination. With the image of the hibiscus in her mind, she tackled the test with confidence and poise. And this time, as she drove back home with a smile on her face, she knew that she had finally succeeded.  The hibiscus had not only been a source of inspiration for Saeng but also a symbol of her resilience and strength. It had reminded her that with patience and perseverance, she could overcome any obstacle that came her way. In the end of the story, Saeng vows to herself that she will take the driver's test next year. One reason she has vowed to herself to do that is to prove that she can pass the test. Also, the flower she bought and planted, along with the memories of the good times she had in Vietnam, gave her the confidence to go out and get what she wanted. The flower symbolized growth and new beginnings, inspiring Saeng to step out of her comfort zone and face the challenge of obtaining her driver's license. With determination and courage, she is ready to conquer the test and prove to herself that she is capable of achieving her goals.

The author includes this in the paragraph to simply be sarcastic for you to know that it is almost impossible for Saeng to take the test afresh. I say this because she was being very sarcastic meaning sheís not going to take the test. For example, if someone were to tell me take a test and I said whenever @LOCATION1 is president again, then Iíll take the test. That would be very sarcastic meaning that it wont happen and Iím not taking the test, instead of just saying No. The author included that just to let you know that the chances of her taking the test is very low.

The geese will return and the Winter Hibiscus will bloom once again, symbolizing the continuation of Saeng's journey in the United States. Despite the challenges she has faced, Saeng remains determined to overcome them, as she prepares to retake her diving test with renewed hope and perseverance. Just as the geese and the plant endure the changing seasons, Saeng too will persist in her efforts, embracing a new beginning filled with possibilities and opportunities for growth.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's strength and encouragement. When she's willing and able she will take the test again with more confidence. Saeng says this to herself to help her get through until she can drive. She's saying by next spring she'll take her test. By next spring she'll be able to drive. By next spring she'll be used to her new home. This paragraph tells that it takes time to do things you don't always get it right away so keep trying. Saeng will persist and eventually achieve her goals, demonstrating that perseverance and determination are key to success in overcoming challenges.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was feeling down about not passing her driving test but when she saw those flowers, she realized that when she came to @CAPS1, she forgot all about her hometown. So, she decided to get back in touch with a nature side and hold off taking her test until the spring instead of rushing things. Saeng's decision to reconnect with nature and take things at a slower pace shows growth and a newfound appreciation for her surroundings, suggesting that she is on the path to finding peace and contentment within herself.

I believe that the author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to show that Saeng still has hope of finding home and being happy. The hibiscus plant symbolizes home and happy memories with her grandmother. When the plant buds, she will feel at home again and be happy, which is when she will take the driving test. The paragraph also indicates that Saeng is slowly getting accustomed to her new home and lifestyle. The familiar honks of the Canada geese and the now familiar surroundings show her assimilation into her new life. Through these examples, the narrator highlights Saeng's acceptance of her situation and her journey towards finding happiness in her new home.

Saeng did not give up on the test. She declared, "I will take the test again." She was determined to pass it. Saeng planned to wait until spring arrived and the snow melted before attempting the test once more. From the beginning of the story where she first mentioned the test, it was evident that she had set her mind on succeeding. Now, as she prepared to face the challenge again, her resolve remained unshaken.

At the end of "Winter Hibiscus," the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story through stating, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again. The author ends the story in such a way in order to reveal the hope that lies in Saeng's future. After failing her drivers's test, Saeng returns home with disappointment and sadness. This last paragraph, however, shows that soon enough Saeng's luck will change. The reader is left with a hint that Saeng will retake her test and pass. Also, this ending paragraph reflects upon Saeng's determined personality to overcome many obstacles she is faced with. This paragraph proves she will not give up even after she was forced to live in the United states instead of her home. Her success in fitting in with her new life is shown when through the quote, "Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become... almost familiar". Truly Saeng is a determined character.

The reason the author concludes this story with the paragraph is to show the girl's resilience and ability to adapt to her new surroundings. Despite missing her home country, the girl is determined to make the most of her new life. By stating that she will have adapted by the next year, the author highlights the girl's strength and determination to overcome challenges. This final paragraph serves as a message of hope and perseverance, emphasizing that with time, the girl will find her place in her new home.

The author plans to do the same thing again next year when the snow is all gone, when the geese come back, and when it's warm enough for the hibiscus flower to bud and bloom again. This is the life the little girl chose, and she will keep up with her new gardening skills until next spring comes around.

Saeng concluded the story with that paragraph because it shows what she has just been through and feels she could go through it again. If she fails the driving test again, then she use the plants to overcome her problems. She may actually pass the test this time. The unique plants show that she is stronger than she thinks and believes now that she feels comfortable with the plants that bring back memories of her childhood. Saeng has discovered a source of inner strength and resilience that she can draw upon in times of challenge, allowing her to face her fears and doubts with newfound confidence.

She shows that she loves her grandmother by spending quality time with her, engaging in activities like gardening together. Her affection for her grandmother is evident in their shared interests and the bond they have formed. Despite her mother's strictness, she still cares for her daughter, albeit in a more disciplined manner. The grandmother's influence on the girl's life is significant, providing a source of love and connection that complements the more stringent upbringing from her mother. The balance between the two relationships shapes the girl's character and experiences, illustrating the importance of love and discipline in her upbringing.

Saeng's resilience and determination in the face of adversity serve as a powerful reminder that no matter how challenging life may be, there is always hope for a brighter future. Just as the waves persistently return to shore, she too is willing to try again and overcome her obstacles. This unwavering perseverance is an inspiration for us all to keep pushing forward, no matter what difficulties we may encounter.

As the final whistle blew, marking the end of the championship game, the players on the field could feel the weight of the season lifting off their shoulders. It had been a tough journey filled with highs and lows, but now it was time to close this chapter and look ahead to the next. With the trophy held high, the team celebrated their hard-earned victory, knowing that they would soon be starting fresh in a new season. The cheers from the fans echoed through the stadium, carrying with them the promise of new beginnings and endless possibilities. As the sun set on this season, a new dawn was breaking on the horizon, bringing with it the excitement of what was to come.

When they comes back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. The flower represents something to her that gives her motivation and determination. Everyone has something that motivates them in life to keep them going, and Saeng has her plant. The author kind of gives you direction and idea where the story is going to go also when the flower buds.

Saeng is not only disappointed from failing her drivers test, she is also upset and missing her home of Vietnam. Walking home she spots a little piece of Vietnam right there in the United States. She buys the beautiful winter hibiscus, or saebba, to remind her of her past. The end of this story combines the two different countries, cultures, and almost worlds her life is from. When she says, "when they come back," she is referring to the geese. To her, the geese symbolize her life in @LOCATION2 and how she has become accustomed to it. The hibiscus is also a symbol of her life. It is a symbol of her life and past in Vietnam. It brings back memories and buying that plant was like getting a little piece of home. When the hibiscus is budding, then she will attempt the test again. When this little piece of home gets bigger, then she will try again. When she is more stable in the @CAPS1 culture, yet still has a firm grasp of her own, then she will be ready.

I believe that the Author ended the story with this paragraph, because I think it is showing that Saeng isnít a quiter. Saeng canít wait until the Hibiscus comes back. It also highlights the importance of second chances and the belief in oneself to overcome obstacles. Saeng's resilience and optimism shine through in this final paragraph, leaving readers with a sense of hope and inspiration for the future.

The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph because when Saeng saw the geese she knew that when spring comes back around she would be ready to get different flowers. Also she thinks back to when she was in her homeland she could see when the flowers grew up from the ground. Although now that she is in the city she thinks the flowers will blossom like the ones back home where she misses a lot. Lastly, she describes the flowers as her friends. She also remembers the "Madagascar periwinkle" growing wild out from the cracks in brick walls or tiled roofs. Basically the author says that she is ready to look for other plants that she remembers from her homeland. She is eager to reconnect with her roots through the beauty of nature that she fondly remembers.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with this paragraph to depict a development in the character of Saeng. At the beginning of the story, Saeng is dejected about failing her driverís test. However, this ending paragraph portrays the change that Saeng undergoes. In the text, Saeng proves to not adapt well to the change from Vietnam to @LOCATION2. She finds solace in a native flower of Vietnam, a winter hibiscus. By ending the winter hibiscus in the concluding paragraph (ìÖand this hibiscus is buddingÖî), the author depicts Saengís change of attitude and her acceptance toward @LOCATION2. Saeng now feels that, like the hibiscus returning after winter is over, she will be able to return and pass the driverís test. Also, the concluding paragraph depicts Saengís new adaptation towards the creatures of @LOCATION2. Prior to her imagination to the @LOCATION4, Saeng had no exposure to Canada geese. In the concluding statement, Saengís mentioning of the creatures displays her adaptation to @LOCATION2 (ìÖwhen the snow melts and the geese returnÖî). This shows Saengís development and adaptation to her new surroundings. At first, Saeng proved to have a hard time leaving her native Vietnam behind and embracing @CAPS1 culture. However, this concluding paragraph summarizes the noticeable change that Saeng goes through. In this way, the author includes this paragraph to note the development in character that Saeng undergoes.

They conclude the story with that because the winter is over and spring is here and it will be beautiful again. The trees are beginning to bud, flowers are starting to bloom, and the birds are chirping happily. The sun is shining brightly, bringing warmth and light to the world once more. It is a time of renewal and new beginnings, a time to leave the cold and darkness of winter behind. Spring is a season of hope and joy, a time to celebrate life and all its wonders. And so, as the characters in the story look out at the world around them, they are filled with a sense of optimism and excitement for the future.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding. Then I will take that test again. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. This tells me that she feels that over time, she will become more familiar with driving, and then she will take the test again. Then she will pass it.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî decided to conclude the story in that way because she wanted to tie in the theme of new beginnings. Saeng is new to @LOCATION1 and has had a rough time fitting in. She misses everything about her old home, from her grandmother to the old plants there. Saeng fails her driving test, so she feels that all is lost. But the hibiscus plant helped her realize she has another chance. The hibiscus can survive the winter and bloom in the spring and that is what Saeng realizes she must do. The last paragraph said ìIn the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.î Spring is the time for new beginnings: the geese return from the south, the flowers start to bloom, and Saeng can retake the driving test. In the last paragraph, Saeng realizes she wants a new beginning as well to be brought I the spring. In conclusion, the last paragraph ties the theme of new beginnings into the story. It shows @CAPS1 new realization and how the hibiscus inspired it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng really wants to pass the test. You knows this when it says "And in the warm moist shelter of the green house, Saeng broke down and wept." This passage shows that she didn't want to fail. When Saeng got home, she had the white bud in the pot, and her mother saw that she was crying. Then her mother was going to put the plant in the ground, then Saeng took the shovel and did it herself. Having her realize she can take it again, Saeng's determination and emotional investment in the outcome are evident.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. First, when the hibiscus buds in the spring that means that the plant is about to bloom. That also means that Saeng will be ready in the spring to take the test again. Also the last paragraph is at the end because if the plant can make it, then the girl can pass her drivers test and be happy both ways.
It's gonna be a year or some change, and I feel like I could have done better. I'm going to retake that test and make sure I give it my all next time.

Saeng was determined to turn her disappointment into a fresh start. Failing her driver's test was a setback, but the hibiscus brought a glimmer of joy to her heart. It symbolized the new beginning she longed for in a foreign land. The challenges she faced - the geese, the snow, and the test - all signified opportunities for growth and change. The geese flying south marked a shift in seasons, while the snow hinted at a clean slate. The budding hibiscus represented the promise of new life, and passing the test would be a significant milestone for Saeng. As the story concluded with this paragraph, readers were left eager to see what exciting adventures awaited Saeng on her journey towards a brighter future.

I realized that my love for gardening is far from over. As I stood there admiring my garden in full bloom, I knew that I would be back when it blooms again. The thought of going back to school paled in comparison to the joy I felt while tending to my garden. Gardening is where my heart truly lies, and I am not ready to give it up just yet. So, until next season, I will continue to nurture my garden and watch it flourish with love and care.

The author concludes this story with the few words “then I will take that test again” because she wanted us to know that she is not going to give up on something she failed once. She is going to keep going until she succeeds with passing “the test.” This determination and perseverance will guide her to overcome challenges and achieve her goals. By deciding to try again, she is demonstrating resilience and a strong will to succeed. This mindset will undoubtedly lead her to triumph in the face of adversity.

The author concludes the last paragraph of the story because she already knew that she should not be afraid of trying a new life or new environment. For example, in the story, the mother says, ìItís flowers arenít pretty, but itís strong enough to make it through the cold months. here, this winter hibiscus. ìIt shows that the mother want Saeng to learn that Saeng should be strong even in times of difficult. Another example is, when the narrator says, ìshe realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before become, through the quiet repetition of season upon seasonÖî It shows that Saeng realized that the new place that sheís leaving right now is almost the same as their old home- In conclusion, the last paragraph tells that Saeng should face the new reality of the world. She should be strong and follow the flow of life. Saeng must embrace change with courage and determination, just like the winter hibiscus persevering through the cold months, adapting and thriving in its new environment. Through acceptance and resilience, she can navigate the unfamiliar territory ahead, finding familiarity and beauty in the unknown.

Saeng's memories flooded back as she gazed at the blooming hibiscus. The vibrant petals reminded her of happier times, of a past filled with laughter and joy. With the arrival of spring, a sense of renewal filled the air, sparking a glimmer of hope within Saeng's heart. Just like the hibiscus that was budding before her eyes, she felt a surge of inspiration and strength. The upcoming test no longer seemed like an insurmountable challenge, but rather an opportunity for growth and redemption. As the hibiscus continued to bloom, Saeng knew that she too would blossom once again, ready to face whatever lay ahead with courage and determination.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî concludes the story with Saeng, the main character, vowing to attempt the driving test in the spring when the hibiscus is blooming. This is a way of showing the reader that even after this story ends, Saeng will not give up. The author adds the thought of the hibiscus on bloom because the hibiscus is a symbol of strength for Saeng. The hibiscus flower is common in her home country and the hibiscus she bought reminds her of everything she left behind when she came to @LOCATION1 from Vietnam. Saeng is trying to accept her new life style and uses the hibiscus as a tool to help her through the tougher times. After Saeng buys the flower she vows to retake the failed drivers test after spring comes. Spring is a symbol of fresh start. Saeng also feels that if the hibiscus can make it through the winter in @LOCATION1 so can Saeng. The conclusion for this story uses a lot of imagery that suggest that Saeng will be strong and continue to live in @LOCATION1.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the protagonist's failure in the test and highlight the lesson learned from the experience. Through this failure, the protagonist is able to gain a deeper appreciation for nature. This ending serves as a reminder that setbacks and challenges can lead to personal growth and a new perspective on the world around us. In the end, it is not just about passing or failing a test, but about the journey of self-discovery and finding value in the lessons learned along the way.

Saeng walked away from the flowers, knowing that he would return to them again in the spring. The vibrant colors and delicate petals had captivated him, drawing him back to their beauty time and time again. As he looked back over his shoulder, he made a silent promise to himself to visit the flowers once more when the season changed. The memory of their splendor would stay with him until he could bask in their loveliness once more. And so, with a sense of anticipation, Saeng looked forward to the coming of spring, when he would once again be reunited with the enchanting flowers that had captured his heart.

The author suggests that if you can't succeed at something on the first try, you should try again. This is exemplified by the idea of retaking a failed test to eventually pass it. Additionally, seeking help or studying diligently can greatly improve your chances of success. By persevering and making use of resources available to you, you can overcome obstacles and achieve your goals.

As the snow starts to fall and the holiday season approaches, it's a time for reflection and gratitude. Looking back on the year that has passed, we remember the challenges we've overcome, the joys we've experienced, and the memories we've created. And as we look ahead to the new year, we can't help but feel a sense of excitement and anticipation for what's to come. Each year brings with it new possibilities, new adventures, and new opportunities for growth. And so, as we say goodbye to the old year and welcome in the new, let's remember to cherish each moment, embrace each experience, and make the most of every day. For it is in these small moments that life truly comes alive, and it is in these moments that we find the magic that makes each year so special.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because the author wants to express to the reader that Saeng has been comforted by the hibiscus and is willing to give the test another try. She is now more open-minded about the situation. In the beginning of the story, Saeng was upset and annoyed about failing her driver's test. For example, "the tearstains on her daughter's cheeks and her puffy eyes. I-I failed the test," Saeng said to her mother. Obviously she was upset and disappointed in herself. The author didn't want to end the story with a sad, unsatisfying ending. Saeng changes her attitude about the test by the end of the story. For example, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." I believe that this attitude was because of the memories of her mother country that soothes her and also her mother. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that to teach the reader a lesson to let change occur and time does heal.

The author of the story "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with the motivational paragraph because he/she wants to show the reader that Saeng is determined to adapt to her new life and home and overcome common obstacles like a driver's test. Saeng had a hard time coping with her problem so she bought a hibiscus because it reminded her of home. I think that the line "and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." from the last paragraph is a symbol for growing up and overcoming obstacles. The conclusion for the story is a nice ending.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, as the return of the geese and the blooming of the hibiscus flower symbolize a sense of renewal and hope. The geese, flying back when the snow melts, serve as a reminder of resilience and the ability to overcome challenges. The hibiscus flower, blooming once again in the spring, represents growth and new beginnings. With these natural signs of rejuvenation, the protagonist finds the strength and confidence to face the upcoming test, knowing that just like the geese and the hibiscus flower, she too can overcome obstacles and thrive.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the arrival of spring symbolizes new hopes, comfort, and belief for the protagonist. The hibiscus represents hope, as she plans to take a test again once it blooms. The return of the geese brings comfort, especially with the support of her mother. As the seasons repeat, the familiar sights and sounds help her regain confidence and strength. The hibiscus holds significance in bringing renewal and positivity to her life.

Coming back from failing her driving test, Saeng is comforted by finding the hibiscus flower. It brings back cherished memories about Saeng's homeland, because it is very similar to flowers that grew by her old home. The author concluded the story by saying "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to compare Saeng to the hibiscus. Like Saeng, the hibiscus must try to adapt to new surroundings. The author shows that Saeng recognizes this connection and is inspired by it. In Saeng's mind, if the hibiscus can survive being moved, then so can she.

The story of "Winter Hibiscus" is a prolonged metaphor for both connections to a comforting past as well as expectance and the future. Saeng misses her homeland but she must learn to adapt to her circumstances, and pass her drivers test. The story is nicely concluded with Saeng's promise to herself that come spring, she will take the test again. The hibiscus flower itself generates this promise as it gives her some closure and alleviates some home-sickness. Saeng's promise indicates that she is coming to terms with her situation. When she sees the Canada geese flying, she has somewhat of an epiphany about the seasons. "Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now." I feel that was a landmark for Saeng and the conclusion illustrates that by allowing her to change.

In "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, Saeng has a deep emotional connection to the memories and flashbacks that the hibiscus plants bring back to her. She cries out of mourning for her grandmother as the hibiscus reminds her of precious moments spent with her. Later on, she takes the plant to her mother, who initially reacts with upset but eventually understands her daughter's actions and feelings. Saeng is upset about not passing her test, and her mother sympathizes with her. The author ends the story in this way to show that the hibiscus holds great significance for Saeng, serving as a reminder of her past and motivating her to continue striving towards her goal of passing the test. This connection to the hibiscus will drive Saeng forward, giving her the strength to overcome challenges and succeed in the future.

Since it is getting close to winter, the geese are beginning their journey southward, and the plants are shedding their leaves in preparation for the cold season. Saeng has made the decision to retake the test, determined to improve her performance. She finds solace and inspiration in the cycle of nature, eagerly awaiting the return of the geese and the blooming of the hibiscus flowers. The sight of the hibiscus holds a special significance for Saeng, as it brings back memories of her homeland and her beloved grandmother. The first time she saw the hibiscus and felt its delicate leaves, it stirred deep emotions within her, even bringing a tear to her eye. The promise of the hibiscus's return next year fills Saeng with renewed hope and strength, serving as a symbol of resilience and continuity in her life.

In the end, Saeng was found safe and sound by the search party, who had followed the trail of footprints leading into the dense forest. She was found sitting by a tranquil stream, humming a tune to herself while picking wildflowers. Saeng explained that she had gotten lost while exploring the woods but had managed to find her way back by following the sun and the sounds of the stream. Relieved and grateful, her family embraced her tightly, thankful that she was unharmed. Saeng's adventurous spirit had led her on an unexpected journey, but in the end, she had found her way back home.

The author concludes her story with that last paragraph because it shows the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus, and how much just seeing it feels. It also shows that the hibiscus motivates her because it reminds her of her homeland that she loves so much and that it's like having a physical memory of her homeland. The vibrant red petals of the hibiscus symbolize the passion and longing she feels for her roots, providing her with a sense of comfort and inspiration in a foreign land. This connection to her past gives her the strength and determination to navigate the challenges of her new life, serving as a constant reminder of where she comes from and what she hopes to achieve in the future. The hibiscus represents not only a flower but also a powerful symbol of identity, resilience, and the enduring bond between Saeng and her homeland.

The author is relating to that when the geese are ready, they will come back, when the flower is ready it will begin bud and grow. When she is ready she will take the test, is what is being said. She is explaining that she needs time just as the geese and flowers do as well. So you can compare saeng to both the geese and hibiscus, because they too need time in a way for when they are ready to do what they do. In a way saeng has molded as one with both objects. This comparison highlights the importance of patience and readiness in various aspects of life. Just like the geese and hibiscus, we too must wait for the right time to act or make decisions. It is a reminder that everything has its own pace and timing, and rushing things may not lead to the best outcomes. Therefore, we should embrace the natural flow of life and trust that things will happen when they are meant to happen.

I think the Author ends this as the concluding sentence because it symbolizes how the girl perceives things. The girl means when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding it means that it is going to be warm again. This symbol of warmth brings her spirit up as it reminds her of her homeland. Being reminded of her homeland would help her take the test easier because she will be happier, ultimately leading to better performance. The comfort that the flowers bring her is essential for her success, as being comfortable is key to succeeding and passing the test. In conclusion, the author ends the story in this way to emphasize the connection between the girl and her homeland, and how the comfort of the flowers plays a crucial role in her well-being and success.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it ties together the themes of love, sacrifice, and redemption that have been woven throughout the narrative. It serves as a poignant reminder of the power of forgiveness and the ability to overcome even the most difficult of circumstances. The image of the setting sun symbolizes the hope for a new beginning, a fresh start after the trials and tribulations that the characters have faced. It leaves the reader with a sense of closure and satisfaction, knowing that despite the challenges, there is always a chance for happiness and renewal in the end.

I think the author concludes the story with that saying because it shows that she is adapting to the new place. It shows that she isn't going to give up. Just like the geese don't give up flying back and forth every winter and spring. It signifies resilience and determination, highlighting the importance of perseverance in facing challenges and embracing change. It serves as a reminder that with patience and persistence, one can overcome obstacles and thrive in new environments. Just as the geese continue their migratory journey, the protagonist is ready to embrace her new surroundings and forge ahead with courage and optimism.

In the short story "Winter Hibiscus" Saeng decides to retake her failed driver's test in the spring because the moderate weather during that season reminds her of home, a place she holds dear to her heart. Saeng's strong attachment to her home resonates with me as I also find myself buying objects that remind me of my old home when I feel nostalgic. Saeng's dedication to her roots helps me feel less alone in my longing for my own old home, a place that holds a special place in my heart. It's comforting to know that others also hold onto memories of home, finding solace in familiar surroundings even when far away.

Saeng knew that she had made mistakes in the past, but she was determined to learn from them and start anew. She didn't want to disappoint herself again, so she made a promise to do better the next time around. With a renewed sense of determination and a clear goal in mind, Saeng was ready to face whatever challenges came her way. She was ready to take on the world and prove to herself that she was capable of achieving great things. And with that mindset, Saeng set off on her journey to a brighter future, leaving behind the doubts and insecurities that had held her back in the past.

I think that the author concludes the story like this because it shows a new beginning. When the spring comes, everything comes back to life. Plants grow back, animals are seen again and the sun shines bright. This is a new beginning for them so it can be seen the same for her. She could try again because it gives her another chance. Another reason he ended the story like this is because Saeng loves nature. Maybe when nature is back around her it will give her hope and confidence to pass her test.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. She had spent so much time resisting the changes that had come her way, but now, in the warm embrace of the greenhouse, she felt a sense of peace wash over her. The tears that fell from her eyes were not just tears of sadness, but tears of acceptance and hope. As she watched the hibiscus bloom before her eyes, she knew that just like the flower, she too would find the strength to bloom once again. The coming of spring symbolized a new beginning for Saeng, a chance to start afresh and embrace whatever the future held for her. And as she wiped away her tears, a faint smile graced her lips, signaling the start of a new chapter in her life.

Saeng told her mother that she failed the test. She wanted to make up for it by helping out in the garden. Her mother ushered her in and started to make dinner. Saeng grabbed a shovel and began weeding the flower beds, determined to show her mother that she was capable of responsibility. As she worked, the evening sun cast a warm glow over the garden, and Saeng felt a sense of calm and purpose wash over her. By the time dinner was ready, the garden was looking neater than it had in weeks. Saeng's mother smiled proudly at her daughter's hard work and knew that failing a test was just a minor setback in the grand scheme of things. Saeng realized that sometimes, making up for mistakes simply required a willingness to put in the effort and show that you were willing to learn and grow.

When the geese return in the spring, the author plans to retake the driver's test. She believes that she will be more prepared by then, having had more time to study and focus. She feels a sense of disappointment for failing the test and not meeting her mother's expectations. Looking at the hibiscus, she couldn't bear to face her mother's disappointment. Therefore, she is determined to pass the test in the spring to make her mother proud and prove her capabilities.

The reason the author chose this paragraph is because the paragraph means that when the snow melt and all the geese returned, the flowers bloomed. One flower she had to run tests on. The flower stood out among the others, its petals a vibrant shade of blue that seemed almost unnatural against the backdrop of the garden. As she carefully collected samples and prepared to conduct her experiments, she couldn't help but marvel at the beauty of nature and the mysteries that it held. The arrival of spring brought with it a sense of renewal and possibility, and she was eager to uncover the secrets that lay within this seemingly ordinary flower.

The author concludes the story by emphasizing the importance of never giving up. She realizes that no matter what challenges may come her way, she will be prepared to face them. The line "Slowly fading into the distance" suggests that she understands that setbacks are just temporary and should not deter her from pursuing her goals. Additionally, she acknowledges the support of friends and family who are there to help her through tough times. The phrase "Through the quiet repetition of season upon season" indicates that by establishing a routine and persevering, she can overcome any obstacles that come her way. This serves as a reminder to never lose hope and to keep pushing forward, no matter what circumstances may arise.

The author concludes the story with this sentence because she wanted to make a comparison between flowers and the test. To finish with this shows she will try season after season just like geese come back every year. Since she tries to make a??? Shows she hasnít given up she will keep trying year after year. Also, it says that this girl is determined and she wonít stop trying till she gets it right. Next, this last paragraph can tell you about the whole story. Lastly, I think it gives a feeling for the whole story. The perseverance and determination of the protagonist shine through in her unwavering commitment to mastering the challenge, akin to the cyclical return of geese and blooming of flowers each year. This comparison underscores the enduring nature of her efforts and her refusal to give up until she achieves success. The parallel drawn between her journey and the natural world adds depth and resonance to the narrative, emphasizing the resilience and dedication required to overcome obstacles. With each passing season, she continues to strive towards her goal, embodying the spirit of perseverance that defines her character.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph so the reader has something to think about. When the author concludes with something like that he/she wants the reader to make their own ending or prediction. And sometimes it means a sequel. It leaves the story open-ended, allowing the reader to imagine what happens next. This technique can create a sense of mystery and intrigue, keeping the reader engaged even after they have finished the story. It also gives the reader the opportunity to think about the characters and their motivations, reflecting on the themes and messages of the story. Overall, an open-ended conclusion can make the story more memorable and thought-provoking for the reader.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it makes the story a happy ending how she doesnít give up and is taking the test again. Also she doesnít want to disappoint her mom she wants to make her happy and give the test a second chance. After failing the test the first time, she realized the importance of perseverance and determination. She knew that giving up was not an option, especially when it came to making her mother proud. With renewed motivation and a stronger resolve, she was ready to face the test once more. This time, she was determined to succeed and show everyone, especially herself, that she was capable of overcoming any challenge that came her way. And with that mindset, she knew that success was just around the corner.

She ends it with that statement to show that she is ready to relive spring in the new country now that she is comforted by the hibiscus. The test is adapting to the new country and she failed it she believes because she had to be comforted by her native plants, but she believes that she will pass the test next year because every repetition of the season allow her to become more adapted to the new culture. When she says "when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again," all those things tell her it's a new year and makes it easier to accept what's happening.

She realized that things come and go but also change. That content times of the year the world around her changed. She had no control over it. She also had to deal with living in a new country. Living in a new country was hard for Saeng. She had to eat new foods, hear new sounds, and see things that she never had seen before. Failing her driving test was hard for her. Not knowing the language and what was going on around her was tough on her. The world around her wasn't something she was used to. She knew she had to change herself and work harder to get what she wanted. Adapting to the new environment, learning the language, and understanding the cultural differences were challenges she had to overcome. With determination and perseverance, she gradually adjusted to her new life and embraced the opportunities that came her way. It was a journey of self-discovery and growth, shaping her into a stronger and more resilient individual.

The author ended the story with that paragraph to let the readers know that she did not give up. In the story, it seemed like she had thoughts of giving up, but her thoughts of her homeland comforted her when she thought she was going to give up. But the last paragraph of the story she confirmed that she wasn't giving up. This showed her resilience and determination to keep going despite the challenges she faced. It highlighted her strength of character and her commitment to overcoming obstacles. The ending left a sense of hope and inspiration, showing that no matter how tough the journey may be, perseverance can lead to success in the end.

I think the author concludes this story like this because they wanted to show that beauty can bring good luck. The protagonist may have not realized the presence of beauty around her before, but now she sees it and feels its positive effects. Beauty has the power to change perspectives and bring about good fortune in unexpected ways. It serves as a reminder that sometimes, all it takes is a shift in perception to attract positivity and success. Beauty can be a source of strength and inspiration, guiding us towards better outcomes and brighter futures. Ultimately, the author leaves us with the message that beauty is not just skin deep; it can also be a catalyst for transformation and new beginnings.

To me it seems like whoever was saying that must have been going through a lot of things and feeling like they were being tested or someone they loved had left them. When they come back, it indicates a sense of loss or abandonment. The phrase "I will take the test again" suggests that the person feels they are being challenged or pushed to their limits. Overall, the speaker seems to be grappling with feelings of loss, abandonment, and the need to prove themselves in the face of difficult circumstances.

The author concludes the story with this because it shows that she is still uncomfortable. For example when she broke down in the flower shop. This shows that even though things can remind her of home it isn't the same. You have to get used to and become accustomed to a new place. This also shows that she thinks with more time to get used to her new home that she will be able to pass the test.

The author uses this conclusion to keep the reader interested and wanting more. By saying, "I will take that test again," the author makes the reader question if Saeng will pass the test next time and what "the test" actually is. This cliffhanger ending leaves the reader curious and eager to find out what will happen next in the story.

Saeng watched as the geese flew away, their honking fading into the distance. She hoped that the snow would remain, keeping the geese from returning too soon. As she stood there, she thought about the beauty of the winter landscape and how much she enjoyed the peacefulness it brought. Saeng knew that once the snow melted, the geese would come back, signaling the start of a new season. But for now, she cherished the quiet moments and the serenity that the snowfall had brought.

There was a specific reason as to why the author concluded the story with that quote. The author wanted to show how the plant gave Saeng a new sense of determination. Saeng previously was upset and tearing the plant apart. But It seemed that she realized how the plant was able to bud to the odds and survive. So she now was determined to battle the odds as well and retake the test she failed. This realization inspired Saeng to push forward and face challenges with renewed strength and perseverance, just like the resilient plant she had once overlooked.
